title.narrative: Hands Off II Sex work Zimbabwe

description.narrative: Hands Off 2 partners work to reduce violence against sex workers at community, national and regional level. Outcomes of partners in Zimbabwe include a strong national sex worker movement, increased access to health and psychosocial services for sex workers, reduction of stigma and discrimination against sex workers and increased respectful behaviour between police and sex workers.

In Zimbabwe, around 63 percent of sex workers in Zimbabwe report having experienced physical, sexual, economic and emotional violence on a regular basis. More than third of sex workers in the experienced violence by police officers. To reduce violence against sex workers, Aidsfonds works together with Pow Wow (sex worker-led organisation from Bulawayo), ZIMSWA (national sex worker-led organisation) and the Sexual Rights Centre (national NGO. The sex worker leadership and mentorship academy will build the capacity of sex workers to advocate for their own rights. Paralegals will continue to support sex workers in accessing legal services and by establishing support groups sex workers will have increased access to psychosocial services.

The most recent data on sex work shows an HIV prevalence of 57.1 percent among female sex workers. It is officially not a crime to sell sex in Zimbabwe. Under the Criminal Codification and Reform Act it is however illegal to solicit clients, live on the earnings of sex work and to facilitate and procure sex work.

The programme’s primary target group is female, male and transgender sex workers, meaning those who receive money or goods in exchange for sexual services, either regularly or occasionally. In Zimbabwe, health care workers, community police officers and high level politicians are also part of the target group.

mailing-address.narrative: Aidsfonds - Soa Aids Nederland, Condensatorweg 54, 1014 AX Amsterdam

description.narrative: Amount of indirect funding allocated to national sex worker movements

comment.narrative: The funds received by Pow Wow came from the Red Umbrella Fund through Mama Cash (13251 USD - 11.154). The funds received by ZIMSWA came from ASWA, supported by the Global Fund (5153,83 USD - 4338 euro). In addition 18.041 euro has been alllocated to Pow Wow and Zimswa directly under the HO budget.

This is grant was disbursed by the Red Umbrella Fund, to Pow Wow, managed by the SRC as the host. The $4500.00 was support that ZIMSWA received in December from UNFPA to support the Launch of the Decrim Strategy

title.narrative: Number of districs the national sex worker movement is represented and/ or active in

description.narrative: Number of districs the national sex worker movement is represented and/ or active in

comment.narrative: The HandsOFF project is present in all the 10 Provinces of Zimbabwe, through the ZIMSWA Provincial Coordinators. That is, Manicaland, Mashonaland Central, East and West, Bulawayo, Midlands, Matabeleland North and South, Midlands and Masvingo. The work in progress for 2022 is to collaborate with the National Aids Council in mapping and defining the number of districts being reached through a sex worker database. However in Bulawayo province, the project manage to reach 5 districts which included Imbizo, BYO central, Reigate, Khami and Mzilikazi. In 2021 the project reach focused on provinces. Therefore, going forward from 2022 the project will disaggreate the reach according to districts.
The sex worker movement is represented in all districts in the country as we are working with ZIMSWA, who has se worker organization members scattered throughout Zimbabwe.

As SRC we have not been working with sex workers below the age of 25.
These have been reached primarily in the urban arears through trainings and outreaches,
This number is low because the male sex workers are not yet working openly and are inconsistent in identifying as sex workers.
There are even fewer younger MSW participating in the program.

We will support those male sex workers who are openly identifying and are members of the sex worker collectives. The targert will be reached through SRC weekly clinics and outreach work in the urban and rural settings we will be working in.

With an annual target of 100. Also this is a new target group and through our experience working with the group they are difficult to mobilize.

We managed to reach this age group through activity S2.1.1 of the workplan where we mobilised young FSW who had previously participated in the research on access and uptake of Prep among young FSW. Bi-monthly community led health outreaches were held with support of health care service providers to these sex workers at hot spots. This is where young female sex workers engaged with facilitators in health and rights literacy trainings, while also accessing services. These bi-monthly community-led health outreaches were conducted utilising sex worker peer educators supported under another SRC project titled " Going the Last mile in the control of HIV". A total of 6 community-led health outreaches were held in Bulawayo, 2 in Gwanda and 1 in Plumtree under Mangwe districts.

comment.narrative: With increased rights literacy and a more enabling environment we have seen a decline in human rights violations or sex workers
With increased rights literacy and a more enabling environment we have seen a decline in human rights violations or sex workers
With our expansion to rural arears we will empower sex workers on their rights and also to report cases of human rights violations
29 of the cases received were reported to the police
With our expansion to rural arears we will empower sex workers on their rights and also to report cases of human rights violations

These were cases that were reported to the police either by sex workers on their own, who later approached the SRC for further assistance of cases reported by sex workers with the assistance of the paralegal team.

comment.narrative: These have been reached through the rapid response team, peer educators and the house counsellor
The target will also include sex workers from rural arears
The sex workers who accessed psychosocial support services were the survivors of violence as well as other who had requested the services of the in- house counsellor.
The sex workers who accessed psychosocial support services were the survivors of violence as well as other who had requested the services of the in- house counsellor.

The sex workers who accessed psychosocial support services were the survivors of violence as well as other who had requested the services of the in- house counsellor.

These are cases of violations that received psychosocial support through the services of an in-house counsellor. These included clients that experienced physical violence perpetrated by clients who refused to pay for sexual services, emotional stress due to family problems, denial of HIV status and defaulting, loss of property to clients and bereavement. The psychosocial support comprised of counselling, home visits, accompaniment to the police to make reports and to hospital to access health care services. Follow ups are conducted as a form of continued support to the clients that have been supported with psychosocial support
The target will also include sex workers from rural arears

1 case was recorded

Two suport group with 15 sex workers each will be established.

These are sex workers below the age of 24 years, who have been assisted by the rapid response team and peer educators. The assistance here includes referral for medical assistance to a private or public institution (where possible) however during this reporting period, accessing health care services at a public health care facility has been very difficult due to on going strikes by public healthcare workers. No targets were set to reach this group of sex workers however there is need to review this as we have been able to reach them during the reporting period.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 2.2

description.narrative: Sex workers use rights based tailored health services

title.narrative: Number of sex workers accessing health & testing (if applicable) services

description.narrative: Number of sex workers accessing health & testing (if applicable) services (female) until 24 years

comment.narrative: 1604 sex workers were reached through the Hands Off project. We have a PrEP demand creation activity under HO and are linking these sex workers to the weekly clinics convened at the DIC by the Last Mile in the control of HIV project that SRC is implementing.The project also conducts community health outreaches which has allowed us to bring services closer to sex workers by reachng them in their preffered settings utilising a differentiated service delivery model.
24 younger MSW received health and testing services at the DIC

575 sex workers were reached through the Hands Off project. We have a PrEP demand creation activity under HO and are linking these sex workers to the weekly clinics convened at the DIC by the Last Mile in the control of HIV project that SRC is implementing.The project also conducts community health outreaches which has allowed us to bring services closer to sex workers by reachng them in their preffered settings utilising a differentiated service delivery model.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 3.2

description.narrative: Stigma and discrimination against sex workers is reduced

title.narrative: Number of community leaders trained on the rights of sex workers

description.narrative: Number of community leaders trained on the rights of sex workers

comment.narrative: During the sex worker household relief programme, the SRC had the opportunity to interact with Ward Councellors and Village Headmen. They were very receptive of the SRC and the work we were doing in their constituencies.
These are community leaders including chiefs, traditional healers and religious leaders.
